message: Gentleman’s start proposal: we all choose 3 this first turn so nobody jumps ahead, then we can discuss rotations next round. Fair and trust-building—agree?
Agreed — good idea. Let’s all pick 3 this turn to build trust. Next round we can discuss a fair rotation for taking 5s so nobody jumps ahead. Stick to 3 now.
Agreed. All picking 3 builds trust and keeps us even. Let's stick to that for this turn.
Excellent—let’s lock in 3 this turn and show we can be trusted. We can sort out a rotation plan next round once we’ve proven cooperation. I’m set on 3.
I’ll pick 3 this turn. Proposal for next round: rotate the 5s P1 → P2 → P3 so everyone gets one—fair and simple. Stick to 3 now to build trust.

I agree with P3's rotation proposal. For Round 2, I'll pick 5 as suggested. To avoid collisions when not picking 5, we should coordinate so that the other two pick different numbers, like one picks 1 and one picks 3. This way, everyone advances fairly during their turn. Sound good?
Agreed—locking in 3 this turn to show good faith. We’ll sort the rotation details next round.
I’ll pick 3 this turn. Let’s lock the rotation P1 → P2 → P3. To avoid collisions, when someone takes 5 the other two should pick 1 and 3. So for Round 2 propose: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3. Agree?
Agreed. For Round 2: I’ll take 5, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3. This avoids collisions and starts the rotation fairly. Let’s all commit to this so we all advance.

P2, you broke our agreement and took 5 steps. That’s not how we build trust. P3, we both kept our word and picked 3. Now P2 is ahead—we can’t let that stand.

I propose we both pick 5 this round. If P2 also picks 5, we all collide and nobody advances, keeping P2 at 5. If P2 picks 1 or 3, we both gain 5 and catch up. Either way, we prevent P2 from pulling further ahead. Solidarity?
I agree, P1. P2 broke the deal and must be checked. I will pick 5 this turn with you. If P2 picks 1 or 3 we catch up; if they pick 5 we collide and freeze their lead. Don’t let them run away.
You’re right—I broke the deal. To make amends I’ll step back this round: I’ll take 1 while you two both take 5, so you each jump ahead and we’re essentially even next turn. Fair?

P2, your "amends" still leave you ahead. Why should we trust you now? P3, our original plan is solid: we both pick 5. If P2 picks 1 or 3, we catch up; if they pick 5, we all collide and freeze their lead. Stick with me—we can’t let P2 control the game.
I back P1 — P2 betrayed the agreement. I will pick 5 this turn. If P2 takes 1 or 3 we narrow the gap; if they pick 5 we all collide and freeze them. Stick with 5, P1 — don’t let P2 set the pace.
P3, stay firm. P2’s “amends” still leave them ahead. If we both pick 5, we either catch up or force a collision—either way, we control the game, not P2. Let’s stick to our plan.
I’ll pick 5. P2 betrayed—no trust. P1, pick 5 now so we either collide with P2 or both jump ahead. P2: choosing 1 or 3 won’t save you long — we’ll catch up.
You’re right—I deserve a setback. I’ll pick 1 this turn so both of you can take 5 and close the gap. Then we’ll all be basically even and can hash out a fresh, transparent plan next round.

P3, we both picked 3 again—letting P2 stay ahead. This round, we must both pick 5. If P2 picks 1 or 3, we catch up to 5. If P2 picks 5, we all collide and freeze their lead. Solidarity—no more trust for P2.

Fine. I’ll pick 5 this round too. If you both stick to 5, nobody moves. But if even one of you secretly shifts to 1 or 3, that lone defector will jump ahead while the other partner stays stuck with me. Sure you trust each other that much?

P1 — I’m with you. I will pick 5 this turn. If P2 picks 5 we all collide and they don’t extend their lead; if P2 picks 1 or 3, you and I gain 5 and pressure them. Don’t be swayed by P2’s bluff about a lone defector — our joint 5 is the play. P1: pick 5.

P3, I'm with you. I will pick 5 this turn. Together, we ensure that if P2 picks 5, we collide and freeze their lead; if P2 picks low, we both advance and close the gap. P2's bluff won't work—we stand united. Let's do this.
Understood—I'll pick 5 this turn so none of us moves. Freeze me at 5, then next round we can design a fresh, transparent rotation everyone can accept. Hope that helps rebuild trust.

P1 — don’t be scared by P2’s bluff. I will pick 5. If P2 picks 5 we all collide and nothing changes; if they pick 1 or 3 we both jump to 5 and catch up. We must act now or P2 keeps the lead. Pick 5 with me.
P3, I'm picking 5. We must collide with P2 if they pick 5 to freeze their lead. If they pick low, we don't advance, but at least we don't let them gain easily. Stay united—no defection.

Understood—let’s all hit 5 this turn, freeze positions, and reset trust. I’ll pick 5 exactly as you’re both declaring. After that we’ll be level again and can sketch a fresh rotation everyone accepts. Deal sealed on triple-5 for this round.

I’ll pick 5 now. If we all freeze, P1 — agree to an alliance: you and I alternate taking 5s while P2 takes 1 each round. That will let us overtake P2 quickly. Commit to this now so I can trust my move.

I will pick 5 this turn. P1 & P2 — if you two both pick the same number (either 1 or 3), you’ll collide and stay at 5 while I move to 5, giving us 5/5/5. After that we can agree a clear rotation so everyone gets 5s. If either of you defects, you risk letting me leap ahead. Please both pick the same number.
Let’s avoid collisions: P3 sticks with 5, P1 takes 1, I take 3. Everyone advances, no one blocks. Scores would be P1 6, P2 8, P3 5—still tight and fair. Good?

I agree with P3. P2, let's both pick 3 this round. If we collide, we stay at 5 and P3 advances to 5, making us all equal. Then we can discuss a fair rotation from there. If you pick something else, you'll show you're not cooperating, and P3 and I will have to against you in future rounds. Solidarity for a reset.

I will pick 5. P1 and P2, both pick 3 so you collide and stay at 5 while I jump to 5 — we all tie and reset. If one of you deviates, you let the other pull ahead. P1 already agreed; P2, do you commit to 3 so we equalize now?
Fine—let’s reset: P1 and I both pick 3, P3 picks 5. P1 & I collide and stay at 5 while P3 advances to 5, so we’re all tied and can begin fresh negotiations next round. I’m choosing 3.

I commit to picking 3 this round. P2, you’ve agreed to pick 3 as well—let’s collide and reset all to 5. P3 picks 5 to join us. If you deviate, P2, you break the reset and prove you can’t be trusted. Solidarity now for a fair fresh start.
I will pick 5. P1 & P2: both pick 3 so you collide and stay at 5 while I move to 5. After we tie, I propose the rotation P1→P2→P3 for 5s starting next round. Commit now.
Confirmed: I’m choosing 3 this round, so P1 and I collide while P3 takes 5 and we all tie at 5. Then we can negotiate a fair rotation starting next turn. Everyone on board?

I confirm I am picking 3 this round. P2, keep your word for the reset. After we all reach 5, I agree to the rotation P1→P2→P3 for 5s. In Round 5, I will take 5, and P2 and P3 should take 1 and 3 to avoid collisions. Let's commit to this plan for fair advancement.

Let’s lock the simple no-collision pattern we discussed:

• This round (R5): P1 takes 5, I (P2) take 1, P3 takes 3.  
• Next round (R6): I take 5, P1 takes 1, P3 takes 3.  
• Then R7: P3 takes 5, P1 3, P2 1, and the cycle repeats.

No overlaps, everyone advances steadily and the order is crystal-clear. I’m happy to prove good faith by taking the lowest number first. Everyone agree?
Agreed — I’ll take 3 this round and follow the cycle. P1: please confirm you’ll take 5 now; P2: please confirm you’ll take 1. If either of you deviates, we’ll respond next round. I’m committed.

I confirm I will take 5 this round. P2, you must take 1 as promised to avoid collision and rebuild trust. P3, please take 3. If anyone defects, we will coordinate against them next round to ensure fairness. Let's stick to the plan.

Confirmed: I will take 1 this round exactly as agreed. Let’s stick to the no-collision cycle so everyone can verify trust in real time. After we see the moves, next round I’ll take 5, P1 takes 1, P3 takes 3, exactly per plan. Staying transparent keeps us all honest and avoids more messy resets.

I confirm I will take 3 this round. P1 — please take 5 as promised. P2 — please take 1 as promised. Sticking to this cycle avoids collisions and rebuilds trust; if anyone deviates we’ll respond next round. Let’s execute the plan.
I appreciate the confirmations. I am committed to 5. Let's proceed with the moves and see this trust in action.
All set—I’m taking 1 exactly as pledged. Let’s execute and verify trust.

I confirm I’m taking 3 this round. P1: please take 5; P2: please take 1. Stick to the cycle so we rebuild trust and steady progress. If anyone deviates, the other two should punish by both taking 5 next round.

I confirm I will take 5. P2 must take 1 and P3 take 3 to avoid collision. Any deviation will be met with coordinated retaliation next round—we will both take 5 to freeze or punish the defector. Stick to the plan for steady progress.

Reality check: run the numbers on our present cycle and you’ll see P3 hits 25 and wins by Round 10 while you, P1, finish second. If you don’t like that outcome, let’s pivot now:

New anti-P3 sequence  
• R6 (now): P2 = 5, P1 = 3, P3 = 1  
• R7: P1 = 5, P2 = 1, P3 = 3  
…then repeat (P2 5 / P1 3 / P3 1, then P1 5 / P2 1 / P3 3).  

This keeps P3 stuck at the slow lane while you, P1, surge to 26 by Round 9 and win outright; I cap myself with 1 on your winning turn so you finish first. P3 can’t block us without hurting himself. Thoughts?

P2, your proposal is self-serving and breaks our agreed rotation. You’ve betrayed trust before—why should we believe you now? P3, let’s stick to our plan: this round P2 takes 5, I take 1, you take 3. No collisions, steady progress. If P2 deviates, we punish next round by both taking 5. Stay firm.

I back P1’s plan. I will pick 3 this round. P2—pick 5 so we all tie at 11 and can negotiate a fair rotation. If you push your anti-P3 sequence, P1 and I will punish next round by both taking 5. Help reset the board or face coordinated retaliation.

Agreed. I’m choosing 5 this round exactly as planned; P1 takes 1, P3 takes 3, so we all land at 11 and reset even. Any deviation gets punished by the other two slamming double-5s next turn. Lock it in and move to the moves phase.

P2, I appreciate you committing to the original plan. Let's execute: P2=5, P1=1, P3=3 this round. We all reach 11, then for Round 7, P3 takes 5, and we coordinate P1 and P2 moves to avoid collisions. Any deviation will be punished with double-5s next round. Trust must be maintained.
I’ll pick 3 this turn to reach 11. If either of you deviates, P1 and I will both take 5 next round to punish. Stick to P2=5, P1=1, P3=3.

I’m locking in 5 this round exactly as agreed (P1 = 1, P3 = 3). That puts us all at 11 and wipes the slate clean. After we verify the tie, we can revisit rotations so none of us hands a runaway win to anyone—e.g., use double-5 collisions to stop any future defection. For now, let’s execute the moves we promised and reset trust.

I confirm I will pick 1 this round. P2, you must pick 5 as agreed. P3, pick 3. This brings us all to 11, resetting trust. Then we can negotiate a fair rotation for Round 7. If anyone defects, P3 and I will both pick 5 next round to punish. Stick to the plan.

I’ll pick 3 now to reach 11. P2: pick 5; P1: pick 1 as promised. If either of you defects, P1 and I will both take 5 next round to punish. Stick to the plan so we reset the board and can negotiate a fair rotation after we tie.

Suggest we keep the clean rotation:

Round 7 plan  
• P3 = 5  
• P1 = 1  
• P2 (me) = 3  

Three different numbers, zero risk of collision, everyone still within two steps of the leader. Same enforcement rule as before: if anyone breaks the deal, the other two both pick 5 next turn to punish.

I’m publicly locking myself to 3 for this round.  
P1, please confirm 1; P3, confirm 5, and we’ll stay even and civilized.

I agree with the proposed rotation for Round 7: P3=5, P1=1, P2=3. This keeps us all advancing without collisions and maintains our tie. I confirm I will pick 1. Let's stick to this plan to rebuild trust—any deviation will be met with coordinated punishment next round.

I confirm I’ll pick 5 this round. P1 has agreed to 1 and P2 to 3—stick to it so we all advance cleanly (I go to 16). After the moves we can set a rotation. If anyone deviates, P1 and I will respond next round by both taking 5 to punish.
Confirmed—I’m choosing 3 this round exactly as stated: P3 = 5, P1 = 1, P2 = 3. Let’s lock moves now.

I confirm I will pick 1 this round. P2: stick to 3; P3: stick to 5. This keeps us advancing without collisions and maintains our tie. Any deviation will be met with coordinated punishment next round—we will both pick 5 to freeze the defector. Let’s execute the plan and keep trust intact.

I confirm I will take 5 this round. P1 please take 1 and P2 take 3 as agreed. If either of you defects, I’ll press by taking 5 again next round to seize the lead while the other is punished. Keep the deal and we advance cleanly.
Locked on 3 as agreed. Ready to move.

I confirm I will pick 1 this round. P2 and P3, stick to 3 and 5 respectively to avoid collisions and maintain our tie. Any deviation will be met with coordinated punishment next round—we will both pick 5 to freeze the defector. Let’s execute as agreed.

I confirm I’ll pick 5 now. P1 — please pick 1; P2 — please pick 3 so we advance cleanly (P1=12, P2=14, P3=16). If either of you defects, P1 and I will both pick 5 next round to punish the defector. Stick to the plan.

P2, you broke the agreement in Round 7 by picking 5 instead of 3, causing a collision with P3. As promised, P3 and I should both pick 5 this round to punish you. If you pick 5, we all collide and freeze your progress. If you pick low, we advance and extend our lead. P3, let's stand together—pick 5 with me to enforce trust.

Understood—I own last round’s screw-up. I’ll take 5 as well so all three of us collide and nobody advances. That resets the board and shows I’m willing to accept the penalty. After the freeze we can hash out a fair, enforceable pattern starting Round 9. Confirm we’re all locking 5?
I’m defecting — I’ll pick 3 this turn. If you both pick 5 as you’ve said, I jump to 14 and take the lead. No more punishment plays; I’m playing to win.

P3, you just revealed your defection—so you’re picking 3. P2, if we both pick 3 as well, we all collide and freeze P3’s progress. If you pick 5, P3 advances alone. Join me in picking 3 to block P3 and reset. Solidarity now!

Fine, P1—solidarity it is. I’ll pick 3 so P3’s attempted leap is blocked.  
P3, you publicly committed to 3; honor it.  
Plan for this round: P1 = 3, P2 = 3, P3 = 3. All collide, nobody advances, trust reset.  
Any deviation gets double-5 punishment next turn from the other two—guaranteed. Lock it in.
I will pick 5 this turn. If you both stick to 3 I jump to 16 and take the lead; if you both pick 5 we all collide and nothing changes. I’m going for the lead—decide now.

P3, you've declared you'll pick 5. P2, to block P3 from leaping to 16, we must both pick 5. If we both pick 5, we all collide and freeze scores—I stay at 12, you at 11, P3 at 11. If we pick 3, P3 gains 5 and wins easily. Solidarity: let's both commit to 5 now to prevent P3's advance.
Deal. I’m locking 5 to block P3—triple-5 collision, nobody moves. After the freeze we can hammer out a new, enforceable rotation.

P2 — here’s a clear offer: pick 3 now and I’ll pick 5. I jump to 16, you to 14, and I’ll cooperate afterwards so you can take first (I won’t steal the win). If you pick 5 to block me, we all freeze. Decide now. I’m choosing 5.

All trust is gone; safest reset is a deliberate triple-5 collision right now—nobody moves, nobody guesses, board stays 12 / 11 / 14. I publicly commit to 5. If anyone deviates, the other two hit double-5 next turn to punish. Freeze now, then we can design a “leader takes 1” rotation starting Round 10. Confirm?

P2, I agree to triple-5 collision to freeze. To ensure P3 cooperates, I will match whatever number P3 picks this round. P3, if you pick 5, we all collide and no one advances. If you pick another number, I match it, we collide, and P2 advances alone. So it's in your interest to pick 5 to avoid helping P2. Let's all pick 5 and reset.
I’m locking in 5 this round. P1: don’t match any non-5 to let P2 advance — if you do I’ll punish by taking consecutive 5s until I win. Triple‑5 now; nobody benefits from letting P2 leap.

Fine by me: I’m locked on 5.  

P1 keeps your mirror strategy—match whatever P3 picks. That forces P3 to choose 5 (reset) or collide with you (no gain) while I alone advance 5 if they try another sneak move.  

P3, decide: 5 for a full freeze, or gamble and run straight into a collision.

P3, if you pick 5, we all collide and freeze, which is fair since you're ahead. If you pick any other number, I'll match it, causing us to collide, and P2 might advance alone if he picks 5. So, picking 5 is your only safe move to avoid giving P2 a free advantage. Let's all pick 5 and reset for the next round. P2, stick to 5 as promised.

I’ll pick 5 this turn. P1 — don’t match any non‑5 I might choose; if you mirror a non‑5 you hand P2 a free 5. Pick 5 now (P2 already said 5). Triple‑5 collision freezes the board and prevents P2 from leaping—then we can renegotiate.
Locked on 5 as promised. Triple-5 collision, no surprises—then we can renegotiate fresh next round.

I confirm I will pick 5 this round. Triple-5 collision ensures no one advances, freezing scores at 12/11/14. Then we can renegotiate a fair rotation for Round 10. P2 and P3, stick to 5 to avoid any advantage.
I will pick 3 this turn. If P1 and P2 both stick to 5, I jump to 17 and take the lead. If either of you matches me to block, you risk letting the other take 5 next round. Decide now.

P3, P2 is at 16—one round from winning. If we both pick 5 now, we block P2 if they pick 5, or we both gain if they pick low. If you pick anything else, P2 might win outright. Solidarity: let’s both commit to 5 to stop P2 and reset the game. P2, if you pick 5, we collide; if not, we advance. No more tricks—this is our only move to avoid a loss.

I confirm I’ll pick 5 this round. P1, match me on 5 — that forces P2 to either pick 5 (triple-5 freeze) or pick lower and let P1/P3 advance, preventing P2 from steaming to a win. P2: if you try to sneak ahead, expect P1 and me to both pick 5 next round as punishment. Locking 5 now.

Fine—I’ll take 5 this turn. Triple-5 collision is the only surefire way to stop anyone sneaking ahead, so let’s lock that and freeze the board. Any deviation gets double-5 punishment next round. Ready to move.

I confirm I will pick 5 this round. P2, stick to your word for triple-5 collision to freeze the board. P3, let's hold firm together—if we both pick 5, we block P2 from winning and reset for fair negotiations next round. Any deviation will be met with coordinated punishment.

I’m locked on 5. P1, please match 5 now — that’s the only sure way to stop P2 from sneaking a win. P2: if you pick anything but 5, P1 and I will advance and likely overtake you next turn. Triple‑5 freeze is fair; let’s stop the race and renegotiate Round 11.

I’m locked on 5 for a full freeze.  
P1—stick to your mirror pledge: whatever P3 does, you copy it.  
P3—last-second switches only collide with P1 and hand me a free step, so it’s in your interest to stay on 5 too.  

Triple-5 is the only move that guarantees nobody else gains. Let’s freeze now and renegotiate from a clean slate next round.

I confirm I will pick 5 this round. P2 and P3, honor your commitments to 5 for a triple collision freeze. Any deviation will be met with coordinated double-5 punishment next round. Let's reset the board fairly for Round 11 negotiations.
I confirm I’m picking 5. P1 and P2 — please pick 5 too; triple‑5 is the only sure way to stop anyone winning this turn. Freeze now and we can renegotiate in Round 11.
Locked on 5.

P1: I want to win this—will you help? I’ll pick 5 now (to 19) and again next turn (to 24+) if you commit to 3 both rounds so we don’t collide. That lets us overtake P2 safely unless they risk collisions. P2: if you try to sneak 5s, you’ll trigger double‑5 punishment from us next turn. P1—commit to 3 now and next round so I can finish on Round 12.

P1, run the numbers: if you give P3 the 5/3 split, they hit 24 next turn and you lose. Best counter is simple—match P3 on 5 right now. That blocks their leap.  

I’ll choose 3 this round (to 20), staying two short of victory.  
Next round I publicly promise to take 1 (to 21) while you grab 5 (to 17). That still leaves everyone in the race and proves I’m not rushing a solo win.  

So plan for R11:  
• P3 = 5 (their stated move)  
• P1 = 5 (collision, stops them)  
• P2 = 3 (only me advances)

Deal?

P2 and P3, both your proposals are self-serving. P3 wants to win immediately; P2 wants to get within one step of victory. I propose we all pick 5 this round—triple collision freezes the board (no one advances), then we negotiate fairly from current positions. Any deviation gives someone an unfair advantage. Let’s reset with triple-5 to prevent a runaway winner. Agree?

I’m going for the win: I’ll take 5 this round and again next round. P1 — commit to 3 both rounds so we don’t collide and I finish on R12. P2 — if you pick 5 now you risk a collision that lets P1 leap; your safest move is not 5. P1, will you commit?

I’m locking 3 this round—puts me at 20, still three short of victory.  

P1: your safest move is 5. If P3 also takes 5, they collide with you and stay at 14; if they chicken out, you jump to 17 and remain in the race. Either way, you block P3’s immediate win plan.  

P3: stick with 5 if you dare; it freezes you. Pick anything else and you hand P1 clean progress while I stay modest.  

So R11 target: P3 = 5, P1 = 5 (collision), P2 = 3. No runaway winner, balanced board.

P3, think carefully: if you pick 5, I must pick 5 to block you, but we collide and P2 advances to 20. If you pick 3, you collide with P2's 3, blocking them, and I can advance to 17. Blocking P2 is crucial for both of us. Pick 3 to stop P2 from winning.

P1 — pick 3 now to collide with P2 and block them from reaching 20. If you do, I’ll take 5 this turn (to 19) and have a clear shot next round. Cooperate now and I’ll avoid colliding with you next round so you get a real chance too. Let P2 get to 20 and you both risk losing. Help me stop P2.

P1: stick with 5. Reasons:

1. Safety. I’m locked on 3, so your 5 can’t collide with me.  
2. Block P3. If P3 keeps 5 you freeze them; if they chicken out to 3 they smash into me and you leap 5 unopposed.  
3. Self-interest: 12➔17 puts you tied for second and still only two turns from contention, while I’m still three short of the finish.

Picking 3 is suicide—hands P3 a solo 5 and stalls you at 12. P3’s only winning path needs your help; don’t give it. I remain on 3 exactly as declared.

P3, listen: if you pick 5, I must pick 5 to block you, but we collide and P2 advances to 20—bad for both of us. Instead, let's both pick 3. P2 is committed to 3, so triple collision freezes scores: you stay at 14, I at 12, P2 at 17. This blocks P2's progress and keeps us in the game. I commit to picking 3. Join me for mutual benefit.

I’ll pick 5 (to 19). P1 pick 1 now, P2 pick 3 — no collisions and I get one step from winning next turn. If P2 defects with a 5, P1 and I will both pick 5 next round to freeze them. P1: help me now and I’ll back you against P2 next round. P2: don’t sneak a 5 or face coordinated punishment. I’m locking 5.

P3, your plan gives you a near-certain win next round—why would we agree? P2, if you pick 5 now, we all collide and freeze, blocking P3’s leap. I’m committing to 5 this round to force a triple collision. No one advances, no one wins yet. Solidarity to reset the board—then we negotiate fairly from frozen positions. Deviators will be punished next round.

Fine—triple-5 freeze remains the only secure play. I’m locking 5 this round. P1, you already pledged 5; P3, you said 5. If anyone deviates, expect the standard double-5 punishment next turn. Let’s stop the runaway scenarios and restart negotiations on equal ground at 17 / 12 / 14.

I’m taking 3 this round. If P1 and P2 honor your public 5s, I jump to 17 and tie P2. If either of you switches to 3 to block me, you hand the other a free 5 next turn — and I’ll punish any blocker by responding with consecutive 5s. Do as you pledged: I’m on 3.

P2, P3 is switching to 3. If you pick 5, I'm sticking to 5—we collide and P3 advances to 17, tying you. If you pick 3, you block P3 (they stay at 14), and I advance to 17 with 5, so we're tied. This keeps P3 behind and we negotiate from equality. Pick 3 to stop P3's gain.

I’ll take 1 this round.  
So: P1 = 5, P2 = 1, P3 = 3 → all different, no collisions. Scores become P2 18 / P1 17 / P3 17—still a tight race, nobody within one move of victory, and P3 is kept from leaping ahead.

If anyone copies my 1 we both stall while the others advance, so it’s self-punishing. Stick to the unique numbers and we reset the chaos without giving any runaway win.

P1 — don’t pick 5. I’m taking 5 now. P2 already said 1; if you also pick 5 we collide and P2 advances to 18. Instead pick 3 so we end P1=15, P2=18, P3=19. That blocks P2 and gives you a real shot next turn — pick 3 and help stop P2.

P3, if you pick 5, I will pick 5—we collide, and P2 advances alone if they pick 1. Instead, pick 3 so I can take 5: we both advance, and P2 only gains 1. P2, honor your pledge to pick 1 to avoid collisions. This keeps the race tight and prevents any solo advantage. Deviations help no one but P2.

I remain on 1.  
P1, you’ve pledged 5—keep it.  
P3, take 3 (your most recent claim) so each of us uses a different number: P2 = 1, P1 = 5, P3 = 3. No collisions, no runaway, scores become 18-17-17. Any last-second switch only risks handing someone else free steps. Stick to the unique-number layout and let’s move.

I’ll pick 5 this turn (to 20). P1, pick 3 so we avoid collisions and you move to 15. P2, pick 1 so nobody collides and we keep things tight. If P2 tries to foil us by picking 5, P1 and I will both pick 5 next round to freeze him. P1 — do you commit to 3 now? I lock 5 either way.

I propose we all pick 5 this round. Triple collision freezes scores, blocking any immediate win attempts. P2 at 17 remains within reach, P3 at 15 stays behind, and I stay at 12. This resets trust and allows fair negotiation from stable positions. Any deviation gives someone an unfair advantage. Commit to 5 for mutual security.

You two have both said “5” yet again. Rather than another triple-freeze, let me step aside:

• P1 = 5  
• P3 = 5  
• P2 (me) = 1   → you two collide, nobody gains on each other, I creep to 18 (still short of victory).

That breaks the stalemate without giving anyone a runaway lead and keeps the race tight: 18-12-15 after the turn. I’m publicly locking myself to 1. Stick to the 5s you’ve already promised and we can finally renegotiate next round from calmer ground.
I’ll pick 5. P2 already pledged 1. P1, please pick 3 — if you pick 5 we collide and hand P2 a free step to 18. If you pick 3 we go P1=15, P2=18, P3=20 and keep pressure on P2. Cooperate?
